column11: Review Text

column8: A bit off the main tracks
column11: Well maintained stone pond in the shape of a lotus.  Can get missed as is separate from most of the main ruins. It's quite peaceful and a nice spot for pics

column8: A Stone Lotus in the Jungle – Magical and Peaceful
column11: The Lotus Pond (Nelum Pokuna) was one of my favorite stops in Polonnaruwa. It’s a bit off the main path, so many people miss it, but it’s a true hidden gem. The pond is nearly 1,000 years old and completely carved out of stone in the shape of a lotus flower. You can see the individual “petals” forming the steps that lead down into what used to be a pool of water. It’s a beautiful example of ancient Sri Lankan architecture and artistry. Standing there felt like stepping into a storybook or time-travel moment. The surroundings are peaceful, with trees and birds, and it’s so quiet that you can almost hear the past echoing around you. One important thing to know—there are lots of monkeys in this area! They’re cute but very cheeky. They will try to steal your food, or even your bag if you’re not careful, so keep your things close and avoid carrying snacks in your hands. It’s not a big site, but it’s definitely worth visiting if you love history, hidden spots, and beautiful, peaceful places. Tip: Go early in the day for the best light and fewer tourists. And watch your stuff around the monkeys!

column8: A solo ruin a bit further away form the other ruins
column11: This place is nice, but very short stop from all ancient town stops at Polonnaruwa. The place is not a complex, but rather a single ruin a bit further away from other ruins. This fact alone doesn't take any magic of the place away, maybe just count with the fact.

Lotus Pond is also called Nelum (means lotus) Pokuna (means pond). It is one of the notable contribution by the King Parakramabahu I and there are several similar pond at the heritage site. The shape of the pond mimicked the blooming lotus petal with 5 layers tiered down to the bottom of the pond, built by granite stone. We were told by a local friend that the pond was meant for the monks bathing back then. Another interesting site to drop by for 5-10 mins.
The importance of water is highlighted when you look at this structure. Amazing how you get a peek into the cultural & religious views of those times!

column8: Interesting pool and never seen this shape before
column11: Interesting structure and I had to see it. The place looks like an amphitheater, and maybe you can sit there for 5mins. Not too far from the main road and easy to find.
Worth stopping to see this.  It is very well detailed and is clearly in the shape of a lotus flower. You will not see many others ponds of such design around. Definitely worth going to

column8: Those Kings sure no how to live
column11: How cool it would be to have one of these in your garden! We travelled this site by bike, which i cannot recommend enough! Take the bike option. It takes a little longer but its a good way burn off all that delicious food you've been eating! ;)

Lotus pond (Nelum Pokuna) got its name due to the design of the pond, which is similar to a shape of a bloomed Lotus flower. This pond made out of granite and has five levels from bottom to top and that depicts how lotus patels are naturally arranged. There are eight petals in lotus. It’s believed that this another creation of king Parakramabahu the Great. Colombo Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapakse Theatre design was done based on this pond. very interesting place to visit in Polonnaruwa
In the museum is a photograph showing the condition of the Lotus pond when it was discovered. It has been well restored.
This pond is found inside the World Heritage Site and gets its name as it looks like a blossoming lotus flower. It is called a pond but there is no water inside
This "pond" is very unusual and unique.  It is worth spending a few minutes here only if you are visiting by car or tuk tuk because it is far away from the more important sites.
This lotus shape pond is so beautiful!... It is small, but lovely!... It is made out of granite and has five levels from bottom to top, exactly how lotus petals are naturally arranged.

A litle out off the road. Around one km from the main road. Turn right before the exit. It much worth the few minutes additional ride. There were nobody beside us. To be at a magnificant, several tousand year old place alone...

The place is little away from the other sites and is located amidst thick greenery. A guided tour includes this site. It is a small pond which is beautifully built and currently in semi ruined condition. The shape of the pond resembles that of a Lotus, hence the name. It is shallow pond and was without water. The place where the pond is located is usually quiet, probably with very few tourists visiting it.
One of the most carved places in polonnaruwa. Amazingly build .It's said that the king use this place to bath with his harem
It is easy to miss this place. Please ensure to ask for directions to get there. The geometry and design in incredible . Do not miss

This pool, originally where Buddhists washed before going to the Tivanka- patamaghara is a bit out of the way and a fair bit away from the main “sights”.  It is a well carved lotus shaped pool. If you visit this pond, you must head further up the track to the temple.
A nice little design although nothing special. It's not worth visiting by itself but it's on the way to Thivanka Image house which is worth visiting so you may as well have a look.

It's small but it's quite attractive with the concentric lotus design.  This is up a dirt road from near Gal Vihara and is a great option if you're on a bicycle because not as many people come up here, and the Thivanka Image House beyond it is worth seeing.

Lotus Pond is a very beautiful and wonderful example of ancient craftsmanship. It only takes a few minutes to visit but well worth it and it is superb.  An ancient pond shaped in the form of a lotus, the flower that was loved by the Buddha. Short drive from the main complex It is an interesting little bit of Medevial architecture and an important stop on the route to many other historical sites nearby. Sri Lanka is an interesting country, and the people are very friendly. It was wonderful and the design is unique and lovely. I can call it as a pleasant respite. The pond is located near the Thivanka Image House but hidden from the main attractions. It is a beautiful pond with the shape of a lotus flower and very pleasing to see the symmetrical shape. Road to pond was not paved as of now. It is in an archaeological park and it roads are being built. The pond is made of carved granite segments depicting the arrangement of lotus petals. Scallopedrings enlarges outwards from lower level to the upper. It is a marvel in design for an outdoor water feature. This featurecan is easily missed due to the artefacts being at the ground. It is a beautiful pond done during the Polonnaruwa era by the great kings for their use. Though we called them ruins, the beauty of this has not ruined. This is good and bad is that that majority are skipping this place. aThe lotus pond is one of the highlights of the visit to the Pollonaruwa site, it's just beautiful and off the track enough to appreciate it in peace, please don't visit Polonnaruwa by bike only because the LP guide says so, I saw people with red faces, nearly fainting for the hot temperature, otherwise take the bike but in early or late ours of the day This design is an unusual for a pond, with several levels to the bottom with the shape of a bloomed Lotus flower with layers of petals and it seems like one of its kind. It can be considered as a masterpiece in ancient Sri Lanka. The basic design has been followed in designing the newly done Nelum Pokuna Theatre in Colombo. It is an amazing task how it was done all those years back considering the workmanship without using modern machinery is unimaginable. This must have been hard work for the people in those years. This Lotus pond is one of the most wonderful I ever had seen. The location, a little bit far from other antics, but in the rainforest, is also interesting. I recommend you to visit Lotus Pond.

Your journey through the Polonnaruwa Archaeological Ruins would not be complete without viewing the Lotus Pond. You’ll need to take an ungraded road, it’s a little bumpy and narrow in places however safe enough.  The Lotus Pond is yet another amazing Ruin, the details are amazing but as with other parts of Polonnaruwa it’s amazing how well kept it is.  Definitely visit this on your journey.
This is the remains of the lotus  pond here.The lotus pond ruins is in a better shape.You need about half hour here.

I have visited many ruins around south east Asia that have similar architecture and stone structures. Cisterns, ponds and tanks are mostly circular, rectangular or terraced. This pond is actually shaped like an open lotus with layers of petals and it seems like one of its kind.
Impressive symmetry and architecture considering it was thought it have been made in the 12th Century. A nice to see rather than a must see.

This one is a bit secluded from the main Polonnaruwa city. If we didn't hire the tuktuk, I am sure we would miss this as we didn't have any guide. This is not a big pond but really a beautiful one! Highly recommend to visit this.

There are apparently several of these but this one has been nicely restored. Must have taken huge effort to carve out the large stone blocks. It's a quick stop on your tour around the ruins here but well worth a look

The pond is located near the Thivanka Image House but hidden from the main attractions. It is a beautiful pond with the shape of a lotus flower and very pleasing to see the symmetrical shape. Make sure to drop by the pond for a few minutes.
Excellent place with History. See it only if you have extra time. It is historical attraction in Sri Lanka.
It is not a must-see in Polonnaruwa. But if you have some spare time, go see it. Road to pond was not paved as of now. It is in an archaeological park and it roads are being built.
It's a tiny pond located on the northern area of the archaeological park, isolated from the main road. It's worth the visit only if you are going to the Thivanka Image House.
There are many bathing ponds in archeology sites of SL. This one is a little different.  It is small.  But the difference is the well made and preserved steps to resemble the lotus.  Worth the look.
it was unfortunately beastly hot .  the ancients certainly had a sense of style and did an amazing job constructing this pond to resemble Buddha's beloved lotus plant!

I did not check anything beforehand so I thought it will be some one more pond with lotuses... Even was thinking to skip that on the road. And it was a nice surprise. Good and bad that majority are skipping this place.

Isolated from the main ruins of the Pollonnaruwa park is the Lotus Pond. It is well worth the extra effort to find a quiet, attractive spot away from the mass of tourists, who can dominate other ruin sites in the park. And have some fun cycling down a rutted track/road to the pond. Nothing very special or dramatic but a pleasant place for a few moments reflection.
Nice lotus-shaped pond on the way to other monuments around the area, although not of any particular interest.
It's amazing to see the beautifully designed pond, without the modern equipments we have now. It's amazing!
Hidden away in the Pollonnaruwa park but it is very attractive.   Make sure you guide takes you there.
An ancient pond shaped in the form of a lotus, the flower that was loved by the Buddha. Short drive from the main complex
Ok to visit not what we expected. I thought this was going to be a large pond with Lotus in blossom but it's actually a large bath with no water in it
If you're short in time during your visit to Polawaruna then skip this one. It's not as impressive as the other structures around

Its a nice thing to see if you go by car or tuktuk. We went by bikes and it was the end of our tour of the site so a downhill to get there was no problem but back was quite tough att the end of a long day.
Walked round here and saw how it was once filled...might have been nice to see water in it though. Decorations are quite nice

The lotus pond is one of the highlights of the visit to the Pollonaruwa site, it's just beautiful and off the track enough to appreciate it in peace, please don't visit Polonnaruwa by bike only because the LP guide says so, I saw people with red faces, nearly fainting for the hot temperature, otherwise take the bike but in early or late ours of the day A lotus pool in a Buddhist country says it all
It seems like Pond was very nice in glorious times . Need more to be preserved for tourists !! May be authorities can give more attention !!

beautiful - amazing to see how it was done all those years back- the workmanship without using modern machinery is unimaginable. This must have been hard work for the people in those years. Everything is handcrafted/made. Superb!!!

The pond itself is nothing much and there is a bit of a  cycle to get to it. As mentioned by other reviewers you can gain access to the pond ruin from the road.  We ( two females) were down here on our own looking at the pond and were followed by a guy on a motor bike who tried to pull my girlfriend into the bushes - he only relented when she hit him and I ran at him. This was quite frightening and I would warn other female or lone tourists that the lotus pond is not much to look at and access is easily gained from the road, and there are few tourists down here thus making it a spot for predators. Otherwise Pollonaruwa was safe and amazing.  Felt I should share this to make people aware of the potential treat and danger by this site

This design is an unusual for a pond,with several levels to the bottom with the shape of a bloomed Lotus flower.Can be considered as a masterpiece in ancient Sri Lanka.The basic design has been followed in designing the newly done Nelum Pokuna Theatre in Colombo.

The pond made of carved granite segments depicting the arrangement of lotus petals. Scalloped rings enlarges outwards from lower level to the upper. A marvel in design for an outdoor water feature. This feature is easily missed due to the artifact being at the ground level and signage being not conspicuous. A must see item in the traveler's wish list!

I saw the before and after photos in the museum before seeing the real thing and I was amazed how the restoration had enhanced the lotus pond. You don't need to spend a lot of time here but don't miss it
Its an interesting little bit of medevial architecture and an important stop on the route to many other historical sites nearby. Sri Lanka is an interesting country, and the people are very friendly.
On a day when the rest of the site was swarming with people, this site was completely peaceful and empty.  It was wonderful.  The design is unique and lovely.  A pleasant respite.
We had to cycle a LOT to get here, and the result was not too impressive. It's a small dry pond area, and not much else to see.

We walked around the archaeological site, we walked a long way 1.5 miles ok if you are cycling. There is a temple with paintings at the end of the track and the lotus pond is worth looking at if your visiting the temple. If you are tired I wouldn't bother, not amazing for the effort.
We had not read up properly about this place before we arrived, hence our mistake. The tiers of the Lotus Pond have been very beautifully carved.

The structure is quite beautiful, however, at the end of a day of truly spectacular archaeological sites it left me a little flat. Perhaps if it had actually been filled with water and looked like a pond?
a very nice lotus-shaped pond. my fave of polonnaruwa ruins :). worth visiting! not many people there too
It's okay but not worth the detour! If you think you saw enough beautifull thing already, it's not a ''must see'', you can skip it.
It's really nothing more than a lotus shaped dry pond. We biked to there and were disappointed. It was quite an effort to get there in the heat and humid of early Jan. So I would not recommend it.

We popped over to look at the lotus pond on our way to the Tivanka Image House - it's really a quick photo stop - nothing more. However, if you like butterflies then there were some spectacular ones feeding on the mud salts in the surrounding area (see photo).

Lotus pond is featured on all materials related to Polonnaruwa ruins. It's considered to be one of the top attractions on the site. This is why you expect this huge impressive pond. It is actually rather small, not that impressive and there are many other ruins on the sites that are way more breathtaking. It is still worth seeing though.
The intricate design of this pond is inspiring.  Gaze at the layers and appreciate the significance of the lotus flower in Buddhism.
The only thing interesting about this pond is the shape, which looks like a lotus flower. Only visit this on the way to Thivanka Image House.
Amazing carved bath from the ancient city, something else to see within the ancient cities boundaries.

Since everything in Sri Lanka is a big Rip off to tourits... i broke in polonnaruwa the way in without paying is into the bushes near lotus pound, there are no roads on the gps, but there are roads there... u just need to get closer to the left side of lotus pound, walk into the bushes and you are inside for free ! must be done with a bike or u can just hire a tuktuk for 10usd, they also know a way in without paying... but before, make sure the tuktuk is gonna take u to all the main places inside the complex... some take u to some randon places that are not important ruins

This pond built in the form of a stylized lotus, has been put back together sinc E the last time I was here when it was a shamble of stones.  It could use some explanation of how it was used, how water was routed here and why it is so far from most of the rest of Polonarewa.  Our guide said monks bathed here, but if there were 2000 of them living here that seems unlikely..more likely for esthetic reasons or for a Use of an elite group.
Actually speaking there is nothing much to see here apart from this small pond which is not even full with water. But it is a pretty site. Just good for clicking a picture.
To be honest the pound was really disappointing. It was small and not that special and didn't even have an interesting story. I will not recommend to visit it, it is a waste of time.
A pond built in tiers of carved 8-petalled lotus flowers, it is interesting in its craftsmanship, but nothing particularly remarkable. Take and photo, and then move on to better sites.
Beautiful pond done during the Polonnaruwa era by the great kings for their use. Though we called them ruins, the beauty of this has not ruined.
More of the fantastic sites of Polonnaruwa. There is a lotus flower on the stone floor. It is worth to visit this location.
Its a remarkable piece of craftsmanship but I just wasn't amazed by it. After a day in Polonnaruwa it just isn't so spectacular in comparison. But riding there with the bike was fun.
There is nothing to see here. Its jus a pond in the shape of lotus. Seeing the image here would be sufficient. Its on the way to image house and easy to miss as its in the forest

when our guide told us to get out the car to see a pond i was not convinced it was worth it, i was definately wrong. This pond is so nice with its lotus shape and well preserved. It is in the middle of nothing so look for it!

While the design is quite lovely and unlike anything else we saw, it was relatively removed from other sites. It's probably best seen post the rainy season when there is water and more lush surroundings.
This Lotus pond is one of the most wonderful I ever had seen. The location, a little bit far from other antics, but in the rainforest, is also a interesting.

This site is within the general Polonnaruwa complex and is a must see if you are going there. It is a very beautiful and wonderful example of ancient craftsmanship. It only takes a few minutes to visit but well worth it.
this is an excellent example how skilled were the ancient stone masons in craftmenship. Beautifully preserved and a must see.

After much temple visiting, it was good to rest under a big tree near the pond. Basically, it's simple- looking but the design was intricately carved from a huge slab of stone. The signs leading up to the pond was just hand-painted so be alert. Was pissed off by a lady walking around the top part of the pond! Unbelievable.
The pond was almost complete dry when we were there but I could see how beautiful it would look full of water and in bloom

This is a little bit off the beaten track so don't think too many visitors get there.  We had a car and driver so was easy for us, not sure would have appreciated it quite so much if we had to slog there in the heat!

I cannot believe people don't visit this place! It is not at all guarded and secured the path seems to be barely walked on! Nobody seems to see any value in this. I hope people will visit this place and it will be better secured!
This is not a huge pond. It is not a spectacular sight. But take the time to look how each stone is individually carved to fit and make the perfect concentric lotus shape. An engineering marvel.
To understand the whole site and the importance of water i loved the design of the lotus pond.It is a well preserved example
No lotus flowers in this pond, just swampy green water with a couple of water lillies.  Not worth the walk over to look at it.
